data.title: Kevin James delivers in “Zookeeper”
data.meta_description: Unfortunately, director Frank Coraci (“The Wedding Singer,” “The Waterboy”) also delivers — an egg. Throughout the talking-animals-help-a-guy-get-his-girlfriend-back formula, James and the cast make a valiant effort to hold the film together. The backdrop of Boston adds cohesion, but then Joe Rogan’s Gale jumps a curb halfway between Kenmore Square and downtown. When he lands, he […]
data.text:
Unfortunately, director Frank Coraci (“The Wedding Singer,” “The Waterboy”) also delivers — an egg.

Throughout the talking-animals-help-a-guy-get-his-girlfriend-back formula, James and the cast make a valiant effort to hold the film together. The backdrop of Boston adds cohesion, but then Joe Rogan’s Gale jumps a curb halfway between Kenmore Square and downtown. When he lands, he winds up at the bottom of the stairs across from the State House.

The cast plugs along. Bas Rutten voices a wolf who helps explain to James’ character Griffin Keyes the finer points of urinating on stuff to attract a mate. The theme that animals think differently than humans comes up repeatedly, but is best expressed in the bonus features.

Working with a live gorilla proved impossible for the crew, so two actors brought Bernie (voiced by Nick Nolte) to life. They sweated, suffered a lack of ventilation, followed James around Boston, sweated, and one of them ran into a parked van at one point. Anyone interested in pursuing a career portraying animals in film should check out the redeeming set of extras.
